title: Euler’s problem was the subject of seven papers by G

1839); additional references appear in the answer to exercise 2.2.1–4. The corresponding numbers are now commonly called “Catalan numbers.” A Mongolian Chinese mathematician, An-T’u Ming, had encountered the Catalan numbers before 1750 in his study of infinite series, but he did not relate them to trees or other combinatorial objects
Catalan numbers occur in an enormous number of different contexts; Richard Stanley explains more than 60 of them in his magnificent book Enumerative Combinatorics 2
Chapter 6. Perhaps most surprising of all is the Catalan connection to certain arrangements of numbers that H
Coxeter has called “frieze patterns” because of their symmetry; see exercise 4. The formula nn−2 for the number of labeled free trees was discovered by J
